focus_skills: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The data set is <math><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math>. What is the median of the data set?
questions.explanation: There are <math><mn>7</mn></math> values, so the median is the <math><mn>4</mn></math>th value in the ordered list. The <math><mn>4</mn></math>th value is <math><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For an odd number of values, the median is the middle value after ordering.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The data set is <math><mrow><mn>14</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>19</mn></mrow></math>. What is the mode of the data set?
questions.explanation: The mode is the value that occurs most often. In the list, <math><mn>18</mn></math> occurs <math><mn>3</mn></math> times, more than any other value.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the mode, count how many times each value appears.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set has a minimum value of <math><mn>3</mn></math> and a maximum value of <math><mn>22</mn></math>. What is the range of the data set?
questions.explanation: The range is <math><mrow><mn>22</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></math>, which equals <math><mn>19</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Range is always maximum minus minimum.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg viewBox='0 0 420 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='0' y='0' width='420' height='220' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='170' x2='400' y2='170' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='40' y='195' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='95' y='195' font-size='12'>1</text><text x='150' y='195' font-size='12'>2</text><text x='205' y='195' font-size='12'>3</text><text x='260' y='195' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='315' y='195' font-size='12'>5</text><text x='185' y='212' font-size='12'>Number of books read</text><circle cx='50' cy='150' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='105' cy='150' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='105' cy='130' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='160' cy='150' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='160' cy='130' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='160' cy='110' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='215' cy='150' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='215' cy='130' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='270' cy='150' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='325' cy='150' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='325' cy='130' r='6' fill='black'/><circle cx='325' cy='110' r='6' fill='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Dot plot of number of books read: <math><mn>0</mn></math> has <math><mn>1</mn></math> dot, <math><mn>1</mn></math> has <math><mn>2</mn></math> dots, <math><mn>2</mn></math> has <math><mn>3</mn></math> dots, <math><mn>3</mn></math> has <math><mn>2</mn></math> dots, <math><mn>4</mn></math> has <math><mn>1</mn></math> dot, and <math><mn>5</mn></math> has <math><mn>3</mn></math> dots.
questions.question: The dot plot shows the number of books read by a group of students in one month. How many students read exactly <math><mn>3</mn></math> books?
questions.explanation: Above <math><mn>3</mn></math> on the dot plot, there are <math><mn>2</mn></math> dots, so <math><mn>2</mn></math> students read exactly <math><mn>3</mn></math> books.
questions.score_improvement_tip: On a dot plot, each dot represents one data value; count dots above the requested value.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A class recorded the number of minutes students spent reading one evening. The frequency information is shown. Minutes <math><mn>8</mn></math> has frequency <math><mn>3</mn></math>, minutes <math><mn>10</mn></math> has frequency <math><mn>4</mn></math>, minutes <math><mn>12</mn></math> has frequency <math><mn>2</mn></math>, and minutes <math><mn>14</mn></math> has frequency <math><mn>1</mn></math>. What is the mean number of minutes read?
questions.explanation: The total number of students is <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>. The total minutes are <math><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>102</mn></mrow></math>. The mean is <math><mrow><mn>102</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a frequency table, mean equals total of (value × frequency) divided by total frequency.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The data set is <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></math>. What is the median of the data set?
questions.explanation: There are <math><mn>8</mn></math> values, so the median is the average of the <math><mn>4</mn></math>th and <math><mn>5</mn></math>th values. Those values are <math><mn>7</mn></math> and <math><mn>7</mn></math>, so the median is <math><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For an even number of values, median is the average of the two middle values after ordering.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set has a mean of <math><mn>18</mn></math>. A new data set is created by adding <math><mn>5</mn></math> to every value in the original data set. What is the mean of the new data set?
questions.explanation: Adding <math><mn>5</mn></math> to every value increases the mean by <math><mn>5</mn></math>. The new mean is <math><mrow><mn>18</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>23</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Shifting every value by the same amount shifts the mean and median by that amount.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg viewBox='0 0 520 230' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='0' y='0' width='520' height='230' fill='white'/><line x1='60' y1='180' x2='500' y2='180' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='70' y='200' font-size='12'>20</text><text x='170' y='200' font-size='12'>30</text><text x='270' y='200' font-size='12'>40</text><text x='370' y='200' font-size='12'>50</text><text x='440' y='200' font-size='12'>55</text><text x='235' y='222' font-size='12'>Test score</text><line x1='80' y1='90' x2='180' y2='90' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='180' y='80' width='200' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='280' y1='80' x2='280' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='380' y1='90' x2='430' y2='90' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='25' y='95' font-size='12'>Box plot</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Box plot of test scores with minimum <math><mn>20</mn></math>, first quartile <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></math>, median <math><mn>40</mn></math>, third quartile <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></math>, and maximum <math><mn>55</mn></math>.
questions.question: The box plot shows a distribution of test scores. What is the interquartile range (IQR) of the distribution?
questions.explanation: The interquartile range is <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>. From the box plot, <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></math>. So <math><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>Q</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: On a box plot, IQR is the width of the box: Q3 minus Q1.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set has <math><mn>9</mn></math> values and a mean of <math><mn>12</mn></math>. Eight of the values are <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow></math>. What is the remaining value? (Enter your answer as an integer.)
questions.explanation: The data set sum is <math><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>108</mn></mrow></math>. The sum of the eight given values is <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>103</mn></mrow></math>. Therefore, the remaining value is <math><mrow><mn>108</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>103</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use mean = total ÷ count, then solve for the missing total.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A distribution of data is skewed right. Which statement is generally true about the mean and median of the distribution?

options.A: The mean is less than the median.
options.B: The mean is greater than the median.
options.C: The mean is equal to the median.
options.D: The relationship cannot be determined from the skew.

questions.explanation: In a right-skewed distribution, larger values in the long right tail pull the mean to the right, so the mean is typically greater than the median.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Skew pulls the mean toward the tail more than it pulls the median.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg viewBox='0 0 560 260' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='0' y='0' width='560' height='260' fill='white'/><line x1='60' y1='210' x2='540' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='54' y='235' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='154' y='235' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='254' y='235' font-size='12'>20</text><text x='354' y='235' font-size='12'>30</text><text x='454' y='235' font-size='12'>40</text><text x='514' y='235' font-size='12'>45</text><text x='265' y='255' font-size='12'>Value</text><text x='15' y='70' font-size='12'>Set A</text><text x='15' y='150' font-size='12'>Set B</text><line x1='90' y1='70' x2='120' y2='70' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='120' y='60' width='160' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='190' y1='60' x2='190' y2='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='280' y1='70' x2='360' y2='70' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='120' y1='150' x2='160' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='160' y='140' width='120' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='220' y1='140' x2='220' y2='160' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='280' y1='150' x2='320' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two box plots. Set A: minimum <math><mn>3</mn></math>, first quartile <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></math>, median <math><mn>13</mn></math>, third quartile <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn></mrow></math>, and maximum <math><mn>30</mn></math>. Set B: minimum <math><mn>6</mn></math>, first quartile <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>, median <math><mn>16</mn></math>, third quartile <math><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn></mrow></math>, and maximum <math><mn>26</mn></math>.
questions.question: Two data sets are summarized by the box plots. Which statement must be true?

options.A: The mean of set A is greater than the mean of set B.
options.B: The median of set A is greater than the median of set B.
options.C: The interquartile range of set A is greater than the interquartile range of set B.
options.D: The range of set A is less than the range of set B.

questions.explanation: For set A, <math><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>Q</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow></math>. For set B, <math><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>Q</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></math>. Since <math><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>></mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></math>, set A has the greater IQR.
questions.score_improvement_tip: From a box plot, Q1 and Q3 are enough to compute IQR; you don’t need individual data values.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set contains <math><mn>11</mn></math> values. Ten of the values are <math><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>22</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>26</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>28</mn></mrow></math>, and the remaining value is <math><mi>x</mi></math>. If the median of the data set is <math><mn>20</mn></math> and the mean of the data set is <math><mn>20</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>? (Enter your answer as an integer.)
questions.explanation: The mean is <math><mn>20</mn></math>, so the total sum is <math><mrow><mn>11</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>220</mn></mrow></math>. The sum of the ten listed values is <math><mn>206</mn></math>, so <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>220</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>206</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></math>. With <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>, the ordered list has <math><mn>20</mn></math> as the <math><mn>6</mn></math>th value, so the median is <math><mn>20</mn></math> as given.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the mean to convert to a total-sum equation, then check the median by position after inserting the missing value.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: Data set A is <math><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math>. Data set B is <math><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></math>. Both data sets have mean <math><mn>10</mn></math>. Which data set has the greater mean absolute deviation (MAD) from the mean?
questions.explanation: For data set A, deviations from <math><mn>10</mn></math> are <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>, so <math><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math>. For data set B, deviations from <math><mn>10</mn></math> are <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>, so <math><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>. Since <math><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>, data set A has the greater MAD.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Mean can match across data sets even when spread differs; compare spread measures explicitly.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg viewBox='0 0 520 320' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='0' y='0' width='520' height='320' fill='white'/><line x1='60' y1='260' x2='480' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='60' y1='260' x2='60' y2='40' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='20' y='155' font-size='12' transform='rotate(-90,20,155)'>Frequency</text><text x='220' y='305' font-size='12'>Value interval</text><text x='70' y='280' font-size='12'>0–10</text><text x='170' y='280' font-size='12'>10–20</text><text x='270' y='280' font-size='12'>20–30</text><text x='370' y='280' font-size='12'>30–40</text><text x='48' y='265' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='48' y='215' font-size='12'>2</text><text x='48' y='165' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='48' y='115' font-size='12'>6</text><text x='48' y='65' font-size='12'>8</text><rect x='80' y='210' width='60' height='50' fill='steelblue'/><rect x='180' y='110' width='60' height='150' fill='steelblue'/><rect x='280' y='60' width='60' height='200' fill='steelblue'/><rect x='380' y='160' width='60' height='100' fill='steelblue'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Histogram with <math><mn>20</mn></math> values: interval <math><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math> has frequency <math><mn>2</mn></math>, interval <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math> has frequency <math><mn>6</mn></math>, interval <math><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></math> has frequency <math><mn>8</mn></math>, and interval <math><mrow><mn>30</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></math> has frequency <math><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.question: The histogram shows the distribution of <math><mn>20</mn></math> data values. In which interval must the median lie?
questions.explanation: With <math><mn>20</mn></math> values, the median is between the <math><mn>10</mn></math>th and <math><mn>11</mn></math>th values when ordered. Cumulative frequency through <math><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math> is <math><mn>2</mn></math>, and through <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math> is <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></math>. The next bin, <math><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></math>, contains ordered positions <math><mn>9</mn></math> through <math><mn>16</mn></math>, so the median must lie in <math><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>–</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For grouped data, use cumulative frequencies to locate the median position.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The data set is <math><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math>. What is the mean of the data set?
questions.explanation: The sum is <math><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></mrow></math>. There are <math><mn>8</mn></math> values, so the mean is <math><mrow><mfrac><mn>19</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>375</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Mean is total sum divided by count; use fractions to avoid rounding errors.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set contains <math><mn>10</mn></math> values. The only values in the data set are <math><mn>12</mn></math>, <math><mn>15</mn></math>, and <math><mn>18</mn></math>. The frequency of <math><mn>12</mn></math> is <math><mn>4</mn></math>, the frequency of <math><mn>15</mn></math> is <math><mi>k</mi></math>, and the frequency of <math><mn>18</mn></math> is <math><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></math>. If the mean of the data set is <math><mn>15</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>? (Enter your answer as an integer.)
questions.explanation: The sum of all values is <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>150</mn></mrow></math>. Using frequencies, the sum is <math><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>150</mn></mrow></math>. Simplifying gives <math><mrow><mn>156</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>150</mn></mrow></math>, so <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate frequency information into a weighted-sum equation for the total, then solve.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set has an interquartile range (IQR) of <math><mn>6</mn></math>. A new data set is formed by multiplying every value in the original data set by <math><mn>2</mn></math> and then adding <math><mn>3</mn></math>. What is the IQR of the new data set? (Enter your answer as an integer.)
questions.explanation: Adding <math><mn>3</mn></math> to every value does not change the IQR. Multiplying every value by <math><mn>2</mn></math> multiplies the IQR by <math><mn>2</mn></math>. Thus the new IQR is <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Spread measures scale with multiplication but do not change under addition.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A box plot is constructed for a data set. What percent of the data values lie between the first quartile <math><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></math> and the median? (Enter your answer as a percent as an integer, without the percent sign.)
questions.explanation: By definition, <math><mi>Q</mi><mn>1</mn></math> is the <math><mn>25</mn></math>th percentile and the median is the <math><mn>50</mn></math>th percentile. The percent between them is <math><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Quartiles split data into four equal 25% sections; memorize the percentile meaning of Q1, median, and Q3.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A data set has <math><mn>8</mn></math> values: <math><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></math>. The median of the data set is <math><mn>11</mn></math>, and the mean of the data set is <math><mn>10</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The mean is <math><mn>10</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, so the total sum is <math><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>84</mn></mrow></math>. The sum of the seven known values is <math><mn>70</mn></math>, so <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>84</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>70</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When mean is given, convert it to a total-sum equation; then solve for the missing value.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A teacher records the following <math><mn>10</mn></math> quiz scores: <math><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>22</mn></mrow></math>. Which measure is most affected by the score <math><mn>22</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The score <math><mn>22</mn></math> is an outlier compared with the other scores and will pull the mean upward because the mean uses every value in the sum. The median, mode, and IQR are less sensitive to a single extreme value.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When you see an outlier, expect the mean to change more than the median or mode.
